comment_text: I swear he sounds just like a more depressed hank green
Too bad y'all don't realize we can't save the planet.

About the cellphones: another reason why they are not allowed is to give the flight attendants another thing to boss you around on ☝🏼

Jokes aside, they’re usually not allowed on planes because making calls on wi-fi can slow down the wi-fi bandwidth for the rest of the plane (the same wi-fi that the pilots rely on for their Wx updates and messages from Dispatch), and also because no one wants to listen to your annoying conversation you’re yelling into your phone over the engine noise. It disturbs a peaceful cabin environment, which the flight attendants are tasked to keep! Can you imagine some annoying self-important businessman or woman just loudly discussing their business on the phone at 6 in the morning? What if they were seated in front of a super grumpy and hungover person, or a really stressed neurotic flyer who is on the way to say their last goodbye to an ill parent? I’m sure an altercation (verbal or physical) would quickly ensue.

The experience of air travel has gotten steadily worse over time. My first flight as a child included a roomy seat, very pretty flight stewardesses, and a cooked stuffed chicken breast served on real china. Dessert was a delicious chocolate mouse. My last flight was an amazingly uncomfortable middle seat, a cup of water, and nothing more for four hours. The process of getting from pleasant, to horrible took many years, and my job required me to experience this decline with frequent air travel over thirty years. 9/11 marked a rapid downward spiral for all air travel.

I married a pilot and his father was a flight instructor.  Every time we went up in our Cessna 182, I had to fly left seat.  I never had a desire to get a license but my father-in-law insisted that I fly the plane  in order to understand aerodynamics.  Planes do not ordinarily fall out of the sky.  You can lose all your engines and still glide to the ground.  I've also flown in soar planes or gliders and these don't have engines at all.  When you realize planes are designed to travel on different air pressures or thermals, they become a lot less scary.  Knowledge is power.

Cell phones do not cause any interference with avionics. The amount of energy that the radio systems on a passenger airliner deal with easily drown out cell phone communications. If a single cell phone signal, if even an entire plane of worth of cell phone signals, could actually interfere with the avionics, the planes own navigational systems would interfere with each other. Simply put, the plain would not be able to fly it all.

This was actually disproven relatively recently. In fact, the origin of the issue actually comes from the federal communications commission. The issue has to deal with the amount of connections a cell tower can maintain at a time. When you're driving around, you may normally be connected to two or three cell towers. Periodically, cell towers drop connections, in order to make room for new ones. So as you drive around town, you'll connect to a new tower and drop from another one. When you fly, moving at several hundred miles an hour, you can connect to multiple towers faster than the old ones can drop you. This ties up network band with, making it more difficult to make cell calls near an airport, even when there are antennas nearby. The issue is network congestion, nothing to do with safety.

As a former student naval aviator, if cell phones were this much of a problem, there would have been safety briefs about it. Not once in flight school did I ever hear a single instructor say anything about a cell phone. Because they don't actually matter. And the FCC and the FAA don't really get that much of a say when it comes to national defense issues, so the military doesn't abide by the cell phone rules.

Narrowly scratched by that "what causes lift" question. The simple answer (though there really IS no simple answer) is: Angle of attack, deflection of the airstream (and, yes, the resulting flow pattern has areas of accelerated flow and low pressure). The shape of the airfoil comes into it only at the stage of optimising drag and maximum lift.

I used to love flying and still like traveling overall, just not the flight itself. Strangely, I LOVE airports since I like to people-watch and walk around.  However, the flight itself isn't great as I've gotten older. I'm tall and have anxiety over lack of control in terms of transportation. Even on a city bus (which has it's own risks like crime) I can hop on and off at will. Planes freak me out during the takeoff and landing usually, rather than the whole flight.   Most crashes happen during the first few minutes of a flight or last minutes of a flight and so it's suuuuper nerve-wracking for me when the plane takes off lol. Once it's level in the air, I can just sleep or read or stare out the window with ease.  I have a ritual for take-off now and it involves syncing my music to it and going into a meditative state and essentially leaving reality for a few minutes haha!

Okay, without all the technical mumbo jumbo. The cell phone thing. Have you ever sat next your computer and speaker system. And sometimes you hear that annoying sound through your speakers when the phone is recieveing or transmitting a signal? Well that is what happens through the headsets of the the pilots. If everyone had a transmitting/receiving phone  signal, that sound can be amplified and is a major distraction and will interfere with our communications. The navigation signals are not affected by this  because airplanes have many redundant and different sources for navigation. But the audio interference is very real. Also, cell phones pose a security risk. So Please set your phones to airplane mode.

Think about how people felt back in the 1300s all the way till the early 1900s. So many thought that flight was not only improbable but some even thought it was impossible. It's not that we couldn't see stuff flying through the air already. Birds do it without thinking and anyone that has seen a tornado or a hurricane can see stuff fly. We hadn't figured out how to achieve flight yet.
This is why it is so important to keep from killing dreams that people want to see happen. To break the speed of sound was one idea and some really thought that the world could have ended. Lol.
Now we are looking at light and how fast it can go and scratching our heads, will this be possible? Cell phone thing is a REALLY old rule that doesn't matter any more. Sure, early analog cell phones with old (60s-70s) era plane technology could have interference issues. But modern cellular technology (even 3G) with modern (90s and newer, which basically all airliners are) airliners have zero interference issues. It's just a leftover rule kept mostly because the airlines just don't want people chatting on their cell phones in flight. It wasn't even an FAA (Federal Aviation Administration) rule, it was an FCC (Federal Communication Commission) rule. The FCC just never bothered updating it.

One of my buddies from college is a flight test engineer at Boeing. He REGULARLY uses his cell phone to "call home" out of band of the plane's communication gear when troubleshooting things on an airliner sent back to Boeing for diagnosis/repair.
Of course we can fly without planes, we have hot air balloons, blimps, hang-gliders, rockets, and so on...
1980’s was a cool touch

I flew on the Concorde once, in the mid 1980s. It was a press junket, when British Airways was trying to create acceptance of the plane by using them for chartered travel-club trips. The club members would take the QEII to England, have fun for a couple of weeks, then fly back to NYC on the Concorde. The New York passengers would deplane, then they’d put the press on the plane — where we got to visit the pilots in the cockpit and interview travel-club members about their experience. They’d fly us back to Atlanta (or whatever city the travel club was from) but had to fly at less than Mach 1. There was a digital display on the bulkhead; as I recall the fastest we went was Mach .8. I must say, that was one sleek cockpit. The pilot said the best thing about flying the Concorde was being home for dinner.
Yep - the shortcomings of the human body explains why airline food isn't very good. The poor quality has nothing to do with it.
